contextId.information: The expressions "the testing," "your faith," and "endurance" are nouns that stand for actions. God does the testing, that is, he finds out how much the believers trust and obey him. Believers ("you") believe in him and endure suffering. AT: "when you suffer hardships, God is finding out how much you trust him. As a result, you will become able to endure even more hardships" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the testing of your faith produces endurance

contextId.information: James speaks of works, as in doing good works, as if they were physical objects. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

James speaks of faith, belief in God, as if it had special power to save a person. It is implied that this faith is not enough. This can be a statement. AT: "That faith cannot save him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

James speaks of faith as if it were alive when one is doing good works, and of faith as if it were dead when one is not doing good deeds. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
James speaks of faith and works as objects that one can possess and show to others. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have faith, and I have works ... Show me your faith

contextId.information: Abraham's trusting in God is spoken of as if it were something that could be brought to its finest state so that it could fulfill its complete purpose. AT: "because Abraham obeyed God, he came to trust in God completely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: by works his faith was fully developed

contextId.information: The quality of wisdom is spoken of as if it were an object that God could send down from heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the wisdom that comes down from above

contextId.information: Here "jealousy" refers to strong desires to own and experience what other people own and do, and ambition refers to seeking your own interests regardless of other people's interests. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: For where there are jealousy and ambition

contextId.information: This is saying the same thing in different ways for emphasis. Laughter is spoken of as if it were an object that could be transformed into sadness. It is the same with joy and gloom. AT: "Immediately stop all your laughing and start telling God you are sorry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Let your laughter turn into sadness and your joy into gloom
